excerpt.rendered: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

content.rendered:
The next major evolution of the web is here.

Immersive content changes everything. It’s a new way to experience, a new way to learn, and a new way to consume content.

The difference is Six Degrees of Freedom or 6DoF, where you are inside of an experience in VR or able to walk around holographic images projected onto your environment in AR. Until now, immersive content was the province of gaming engines, and experiences could only be created in Unity (C#) and UnReal engine (C++) and deliver them through platform-specific app stores. Using JavaScript web developers can create experiences in WebXR and distribute them over the web directly into headsets.

This site is designed to be used in an immersive browser. Oculus Quest’s native browser and Mozilla’s Firefox Reality brings immersive content to your headset, all you have to do is load a WebXR site and enter the immersive session.

title.rendered: WebXR Standards and Accessibility Architecture Issues

content.rendered: An excellent primer on understanding WebXR itself, but also as it relates to accessibility.

transform-style: detached is a proposed attribute that can separate a div on the z-access from the plane of a web-page viewed on a stereoscopic device. It has been proposed to the W3C but is not seen progress. If you have the power to lobby for this, detached CSS needs a champion for Chromium and Firefox.
